title: Fact Check: Was Planned Parenthood Started To 'Control' The Black ...
summary: The NPR article addresses the allegations made by Ben Carson, a Republican presidential candidate, claiming that Planned Parenthood was established to control the black population and critiques its founder, Margaret Sanger, for supporting eugenics. Carson contends that most Planned Parenthood clinics are located in black neighborhoods to control their population, echoing similar criticisms made in the past. Planned Parenthood responded, refuting Carson’s claims and highlighting his misrepresentation of the data and racial access issues to reproductive services. Although Margaret Sanger was associated with the eugenics movement, historians debate the extent of her involvement. She emphasized that birth control should empower individuals to have the children they desire, rather than focussing on race or coercion. The Guttmacher Institute found that the majority of abortion providers, including Planned Parenthood, are situated in predominantly white neighborhoods. Furthermore, Sanger had opposed Nazi Germany, dismantling any claims of her connection to the regime. Despite these discussions, the article acknowledged historical complexities surrounding the availability of reproductive services and racial disparities in U.S. health care.

title: Research Shows Planned Parenthood Expands Targeting Minorities as it ...
summary: Research indicates that Planned Parenthood places a significant number of its abortion facilities near minority neighborhoods. Specifically, 86% of these facilities are located in or near minority communities in the 25 U.S. counties with the highest abortion rates. These counties house 19% of the U.S. population but a disproportionate 28% of the black population and 37% of the Hispanic/Latino population, contributing to higher abortion rates within these groups. Despite minorities comprising smaller overall percentages of the U.S. population (blacks at 12.6% and Hispanics/Latinos at 16.3%), they account for a substantial portion of abortions. In New York City, for example, minorities made up 53% of the population but received 72% of the abortions in 2014. The Life Issues Institute's research shows that 49% of zip codes within five miles of Planned Parenthood facilities have minority populations at least double the national average, with a majority being more than 50% minority. Even though Planned Parenthood of Greater New York has recently renounced its founder Margaret Sanger's eugenics stance, the data suggests that the organization continues to target minority communities in its abortion services.
snippet: New research shows that Planned Parenthood has located a stunning 86 percent of its abortion facilities in or near minority neighborhoods in the 25 U.S. counties with the most abortions.

title: Planned Parenthood Puts 86% of Its Abortion Facilities in Minority ...
summary: New research by the Life Issues Institute indicates that 86% of Planned Parenthood's abortion facilities are situated in or near African American and Latino neighborhoods. This analysis, based on 2010 Census data for the 25 U.S. counties with the highest abortion rates, reports that 30% of abortions in 2014 occurred in these areas. Between 2010 and 2018, Planned Parenthood increased its facilities in these counties by 35%. Their largest facilities, or mega abortion centers, are near black and Latino neighborhoods. Moreover, 49% of zip codes within a five-mile radius of these facilities have minority populations significantly surpassing national averages, and 75% of the facilities are in or near minority zip codes. The text criticizes Planned Parenthood's history of targeting minority communities, drawing connections to its founder Margaret Sanger's eugenics beliefs. The narrative notes that, since 1973, an estimated 20 million unborn black babies have been aborted, with a significant number in Planned Parenthood clinics. The organization is described as a major abortion provider in the U.S., recording over 345,000 abortions last year.

title: Fact Check: Most Abortion Clinics Are Not in Communities of Color - BET
summary: A study by the Guttmacher Institute found that most abortion clinics in the United States are not located in communities of color. Specifically, 60% of clinics offering abortions are in predominantly white neighborhoods, with only 6% in Black neighborhoods, 13% in Latino areas, and 18% in racially diverse communities. For clinics performing more than 400 abortions annually, 58% are in mostly white areas, 9% in Black communities, 16% in Latino areas, and 16% in racially diverse locations. Dr. Vanessa Cullins from Planned Parenthood affirms the reliability of these findings, noting that they counter the claim that a majority of abortion providers are in Black neighborhoods. The article emphasizes the importance of focusing on access to reproductive health care, rather than on misleading narratives about the locations of clinics.

title: Candace Owens: Murdering Black Babies Is Now Called 'Health Care'
summary: Candace Owens, a communications director for Turning Point USA and conservative activist, criticized Planned Parenthood on Twitter, labeling their services as targeting the black community. Owens referenced Planned Parenthood's tweet stating 'Abortion is health care', arguing that it equates to murder, particularly of black babies. Ryan Bomberger of the Radiance Foundation also criticized Planned Parenthood for allegedly focusing their services on African-American communities, citing historical claims of racial targeting and a high percentage of abortion facilities located near minority neighborhoods. According to data, a significant percentage of abortions involve black and Hispanic women, despite their smaller representation in the overall U.S. population. Between 2013 and 2015, Planned Parenthood reportedly received $1.5 billion in taxpayer funds.
